prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: It will often be difficult to establish that a recipient of information actually obtained it. This is particularly so where, by trial and error or through publicly available information, the individual claims to have obtained the information on his or her own.[1]

A number of devices can be employed which provide the employer with excellent supportive evidence. For example, where possible, minutes should be made of any discussions which take place during negotiations or meetings. The minutes should include such information as the individuals present, the place of the meeting, a list of any documents produced, and a notation of any property, machinery, facilities, laboratories, etc. visited. In addition, written confirmation letters following meetings may be useful to confirm much of the same information.

With respect to ongoing documentation, it is recommended that personnel records and performance appraisals address issues of confidentiality and non-competition as they arise. Such documents should be detailed and will provide useful evidence if necessary. The behaviour of the employee during the employment relationship may also provide evidence of his or her understanding that certain information was to remain confidential.

Of key importance to the courts will be the circumstances under which the employment relationship comes to an end. Accordingly, employers should be sure to maintain appropriate records in relation to the termination of or resignation from employment. In addition, evidence of improper activities by the employee prior to departure should be gathered. This would include:
contacting the employer's customers, suppliers or employees with a view to competition;
taking information in documentary or other forms (such as computer disks);
misuse of company funds or resources (charges for the use of telephones, facsimiles, couriers, etc.);
improper use of company property (vehicles, pagers, facilities, boardrooms, etc.).
